title: EMS Incident Dispatch Data
ufd: This dataset contains information about EMS incident dispatches, from the initial call to the closing of the incident. It includes details on the type of call (e.g., injury, drug-related), the severity level, and timestamps for various stages of the response, such as when the incident was first assigned, when responders arrived on the scene, and when the patient arrived at the hospital. The dataset also provides information on the location of the incident, including the borough, dispatch area, and zip code. Key columns include `incident_datetime`, `initial_call_type`, `final_call_type`, `dispatch_response_seconds_qy` (dispatch response time in seconds), and geographic information. Researchers and public safety analysts can use this data to analyze response times, identify trends in incident types, and assess resource allocation across different areas. The `held_indicator` and `reopen_indicator` columns can be used to understand incident management processes. Please note that to protect personal information, specific locations have been aggregated.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details EMS incident dispatches, encompassing the entire incident lifecycle from initial call to closure. It includes information on call types, severity levels, timestamps for response stages (dispatch, arrival, hospital arrival), and location details (borough, dispatch area, zip code). The data allows for analysis of response times, incident trends, and resource allocation.

Related Topics:
- Emergency Medical Services (EMS)
- Public Health
- Incident Response
- Geographic Analysis
- Resource Allocation
- Urban Planning
- Public Safety
- Dispatch Operations

Concepts and Synonyms:
- EMS Incident: Emergency Medical Service Event, 911 Call, Medical Emergency
- Dispatch Response Time: Response Time, Time to Dispatch, Time to Scene
- Initial Call Type: Complaint Type, Nature of Call, Reason for Dispatch
- Final Call Type: Incident Outcome, Resolution Type, Disposition
- Geographic Location: Incident Location, Borough, Dispatch Area, Zip Code
- Severity Level: Priority, Urgency, Call Classification

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze EMS response times across different boroughs and zip codes.
- Identify trends in specific incident types (e.g., drug-related incidents) over time.
- Evaluate the impact of resource allocation on response times and patient outcomes.
- Develop predictive models for forecasting EMS demand in different areas.
- Optimize dispatch protocols to improve efficiency and reduce response times.
- Study the relationship between socioeconomic factors and EMS incident rates.
- Assess the effectiveness of public health interventions on reducing specific types of emergencies.

title: Modified Zip Code Tabulation Areas (MODZCTA)
ufd: This dataset provides geographic boundaries for Modified Zip Code Tabulation Areas (MODZCTA) in New York City. MODZCTAs are a custom geographic aggregation of zip codes used by the NYC Department of Health & Mental Hygiene (DOHMH) for mapping health-related data, particularly for COVID-19 analysis. The dataset includes the MODZCTA code, a label, the corresponding 2010 Census ZCTA(s), and a population estimate. The `the_geom` column contains the geospatial data defining the boundaries of each MODZCTA. Researchers and public health officials can use this dataset to visualize and analyze health data at the MODZCTA level, identify areas with specific health needs, and inform public health interventions. The population estimates can be used to calculate rates and per capita measures.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains geographic boundaries for Modified Zip Code Tabulation Areas (MODZCTA) in New York City. MODZCTAs are custom geographic aggregations of zip codes used by the NYC DOHMH for health data mapping, especially for COVID-19 analysis. The dataset includes MODZCTA codes, labels, corresponding 2010 Census ZCTAs, population estimates, and geospatial data.

Related Topics:
- Public Health
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)
- Epidemiology
- Urban Planning
- Demographics
- COVID-19
- New York City

Concepts and Synonyms:
- MODZCTA: Modified Zip Code Tabulation Area, custom zip code aggregation
- ZCTA: Zip Code Tabulation Area, Census ZCTA
- Geospatial Data: geographic boundaries, shapefiles, `the_geom` column
- Population Estimates: demographic data, population counts
- NYC DOHMH: New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene
- Health Data Mapping: disease mapping, spatial epidemiology

Applications and Use Cases:
- Visualize and analyze health data at the MODZCTA level.
- Identify areas with specific health needs or health disparities.
- Calculate rates and per capita measures using population estimates.
- Inform public health interventions and resource allocation.
- Map COVID-19 incidence and prevalence across NYC.
- Integrate with other datasets containing health indicators.

title: Street Hail Livery (SHL) Drivers - Active
ufd: This dataset contains information about active, licensed Street Hail Livery (SHL) drivers in New York City. Each row represents a driver and includes their license number, name, status, and license expiration date. The `license_number` is a unique identifier for each driver, and the `name` column provides the driver's name. The `status_description` indicates the driver's current status, which is "SHL UNRESTRICTED" for all entries in this sample, meaning they are authorized to operate SHL vehicles. The `expiration_date` shows when the driver's license expires. This dataset is updated daily, with the `last_update_date` and `last_update_time` reflecting the most recent update. You can use this dataset to verify the status of SHL drivers or analyze license expiration trends.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides details on active, licensed Street Hail Livery (SHL) drivers in New York City. It includes information such as license number, driver name, license status (currently "SHL UNRESTRICTED" for all entries), and license expiration date. The dataset is updated daily, offering a current snapshot of SHL driver licensing.

Related Topics:
- Street Hail Livery (SHL)
- Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC)
- Driver Licensing
- Transportation Regulation
- New York City Transportation

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Street Hail Livery (SHL): For-hire vehicle, taxi, cab
- License Number: Driver ID, unique identifier
- Status Description: License status, active status, authorization status
- Expiration Date: License renewal date, validity period
- SHL UNRESTRICTED: Fully licensed, authorized to operate

Applications and Use Cases:
- Verify the license status of SHL drivers.
- Analyze trends in SHL driver license expirations.
- Monitor the number of active SHL drivers in NYC.
- Support regulatory oversight and compliance efforts related to SHL drivers.
- Develop applications for driver verification or transportation management.

title: BUILDING
ufd: This dataset provides detailed information about building footprints in New York City, offering insights into the city's built environment. Each row represents a building footprint, with its geometry described in the `the_geom` column, allowing for spatial analysis. Key attributes include the building identification number (`bin`), Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications ID (`doitt_id`), the building's base BBL (`base_bbl`) and its construction year (`construction_year`). The `shape_area` and `shape_length` columns provide measurements of the building footprint. Additional data includes the source of the geometry (`geom_source`), ground elevation (`ground_elevation`), and roof height (`height_roof`). Researchers, urban planners, and developers can use this dataset to analyze building characteristics, assess urban development patterns, and support various city planning initiatives.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains detailed building footprint information for New York City. It includes geometric data, unique identifiers, construction year, and measurements like area and length for each building. The data allows for spatial analysis and understanding of the city's built environment.

Related Topics:
- Urban Planning
- City Development
- Spatial Analysis
- Building Information
- New York City
- Geographic Data

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Building Footprint: Building outline, building polygon, structure boundary
- BBL: Borough, Block, Lot; property identification
- BIN: Building Identification Number
- DOITT_ID: Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications ID
- Construction Year: Year Built, Year of Construction
- Shape_Area: Building Area, Footprint Area
- Shape_Length: Building Perimeter, Footprint Length
- Geom_Source: Geometry Source, Data Source
- Ground_Elevation: Elevation, Ground Level
- Height_Roof: Roof Height, Building Height

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyzing building density and distribution across NYC.
- Assessing the impact of new developments on existing infrastructure.
- Identifying areas with older buildings for potential renovation or redevelopment.
- Creating 3D city models for visualization and simulation.
- Supporting urban planning initiatives related to zoning and land use.
- Studying the relationship between building characteristics and environmental factors.
- Evaluating the impact of building height on shadow patterns.

title: City Record Online
ufd: This dataset provides a searchable database of notices published in the City Record newspaper. It includes information on public hearings and meetings, auctions and sales, solicitations and awards, and official rules proposed and adopted by city agencies. Key columns include `request_id`, `start_date`, `end_date`, `agency_name`, `short_title`, and `section_name`. The `agency_name` column indicates the specific city agency involved, while `short_title` and `section_name` describe the type of notice. The `additional_description_1` column provides further details, such as effective dates, job titles, and salary information for personnel changes. Researchers and the public can use this dataset to track city government activities, monitor personnel changes, and identify procurement opportunities. The dataset also contains contact information for specific notices, such as phone numbers and email addresses.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains a comprehensive record of notices published in the City Record, offering insights into the inner workings of city government. It includes details on public hearings, auctions, solicitations, rule changes, and personnel actions across various city agencies. Users can search and filter by agency, notice type, date, and keywords to track specific government activities and opportunities.

Related Topics:
- City government transparency
- Public administration
- Municipal finance
- Procurement
- Regulatory compliance
- Public hearings and meetings

Concepts and Synonyms:
- City Record: Official journal, public notice publication, government gazette
- Agency Name: Department, bureau, commission, city entity
- Solicitation: Bid, RFP (Request for Proposal), procurement opportunity, contract
- Public Hearing: Meeting, open forum, community input session
- Rule Change: Regulation, ordinance, policy amendment, legislation
- Personnel Action: Hiring, promotion, salary change, appointment

Applications and Use Cases:
- Tracking proposed rule changes by specific city agencies.
- Identifying upcoming public hearings related to zoning or development.
- Monitoring procurement opportunities and contract awards.
- Researching personnel changes and salary information within city government.
- Analyzing trends in city government activity over time.
- Finding contact information for specific notices and inquiries.

title: Property Valuation and Assessment Data
ufd: This dataset contains property valuation and assessment data for properties in New York City, collected by the Department of Finance. It includes information used to calculate property tax bills. Key columns include 'boro' (borough), 'block', 'lot', 'owner', 'bldgcl' (building class), and 'taxclass'. The dataset also provides details on lot dimensions ('ltfront', 'ltdepth'), building characteristics ('stories'), and property values ('fullval', 'avland', 'avtot'). Researchers, city planners, and real estate professionals can use this data to analyze property values, understand tax assessments, and gain insights into land use patterns in NYC. The data covers the assessment period of 2018/19.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed property valuation and assessment information for properties in New York City during the 2018/19 assessment period. Compiled by the Department of Finance, it includes key data points like borough, block, lot, building class, tax class, property dimensions, building characteristics, and assessed values. This data is crucial for understanding property tax calculations and land use patterns across the city.

  - Real Estate

  - New York City
  - Land Use
  - Municipal Finance

  - Building Class: Bldgcl, Property Type, Land Use Code
  - Lot Dimensions: Ltfront, Ltdepth, Property Size, Parcel Size
  - Assessed Value: Fullval, Avland, Avtot, Taxable Value

Applications and Use Cases:
  - Analyze property value trends across different boroughs.

  - Identify areas with high or low property values for urban planning purposes.
  - Investigate the relationship between building characteristics and assessed values.
  - Compare property tax burdens across different property types.
  - Support real estate investment decisions.

title: NYPD Calls for Service (Year to Date)
ufd: This dataset contains information about calls for service to the NYPD's 911 system, documenting each entry into the ICAD system. It includes details on incidents reported by the public and self-initiated entries by NYPD personnel. Key columns include `incident_date` and `incident_time`, specifying when the incident occurred, `nypd_pct_cd` indicating the police precinct, and `boro_nm` representing the borough where the incident took place. The `typ_desc` column provides a description of the incident type, while `latitude` and `longitude` offer geographic coordinates. Researchers and public safety analysts can use this data to analyze incident trends, response times, and resource allocation across different areas of New York City. The dataset also includes timestamps for when the call was added (`add_ts`), dispatched (`disp_ts`), when officers arrived (`arrivd_ts`), and when the incident was closed (`closng_ts`).
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details calls for service to the NYPD 911 system, capturing incidents reported by the public and self-initiated actions by NYPD personnel. It includes information on incident type, location (borough, precinct, latitude, longitude), and timestamps for key stages like call addition, dispatch, arrival, and closure. Researchers and analysts can use this data to study crime patterns, response times, and resource allocation within New York City.

Related Topics:
- Crime Statistics
- Emergency Response
- Law Enforcement
- Urban Planning
- Public Health
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)

Concepts and Synonyms:
- 911 Calls: Emergency calls, calls for service, incident reports
- NYPD: New York Police Department, law enforcement agency
- Incident Type: Crime type, offense description, typ_desc
- Precinct: Police precinct, nypd_pct_cd, police district
- Borough: Boro_nm, city borough, administrative division
- Response Time: Arrivd_ts - disp_ts, time to arrival, emergency response duration
- Geographic Coordinates: Latitude, longitude, geospatial data, location data

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze crime hotspots and trends across different boroughs and precincts.
- Evaluate NYPD response times to different types of incidents.
- Optimize resource allocation based on incident frequency and severity.
- Visualize incident locations on a map to identify patterns.
- Study the relationship between incident types and socio-economic factors.
- Develop predictive models for crime forecasting.
- Assess the impact of public safety initiatives on crime rates.

title: 2021 Yellow Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip records for yellow taxis in 2021. Each row represents a single taxi trip, including details about pick-up and drop-off times and locations. You can identify the taxi company using the `vendorid` and the specific pick-up and drop-off zones via `pulocationid` and `dolocationid`, respectively. The dataset also provides information on the number of passengers (`passenger_count`) and the distance traveled (`trip_distance`). Furthermore, it breaks down the fare into different components such as `fare_amount`, `tip_amount`, `tolls_amount`, and other surcharges, culminating in the `total_amount`. Researchers and analysts can use this data to study taxi ridership patterns, analyze fare structures, or build predictive models for trip demand. The `store_and_fwd_flag` indicates if the trip record was temporarily stored in the vehicle before being sent to the vendor.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed trip information for yellow taxis in 2021. It includes pick-up and drop-off locations and times, passenger count, trip distance, and a breakdown of fare components. The data allows for analysis of taxi ridership patterns and fare structures.

Related Topics:
- Taxi trips
- Transportation data
- Fare analysis
- Geographic data
- Ridership patterns

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Vendor ID: Taxi company identifier
- PULocationID: Pick-up location ID
- DOLocationID: Drop-off location ID
- Trip Distance: Distance traveled
- Fare Amount: Base fare
- Tip Amount: Gratuity
- Total Amount: Total fare including all charges
- Store and Forward Flag: Data transmission delay indicator

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze taxi ridership trends over time.
- Predict taxi demand based on location and time.
- Study the impact of tolls and surcharges on taxi fares.
- Identify popular pick-up and drop-off locations.
- Build a model to estimate trip costs.

title: Popular Baby Names
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the popularity of baby names in 2021. Specifically, it focuses on female names within the Asian and Pacific Islander ethnic group. Each row represents a unique name and its corresponding count, indicating how many times that name was registered. The 'rnk' column shows the popularity rank of each name, with lower numbers indicating higher popularity. Researchers and parents can use this data to explore naming trends and identify popular names within this demographic. The dataset includes the birth year ('brth_yr'), gender ('gndr'), ethnicity ('ethcty'), name ('nm'), count ('cnt'), and rank ('rnk'). Be mindful when interpreting ranks with low frequency counts, as these can fluctuate.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the popularity of female baby names within the Asian and Pacific Islander ethnic group in 2021. It includes the name, count of occurrences, and popularity rank for each name. The data allows for analysis of naming trends and identification of common names within this specific demographic.

Related Topics:
- Baby Names
- Demographics
- Ethnicity
- Naming Trends
- Population Statistics

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Baby Names: Infant Names, First Names, Given Names
- Popularity Rank: Ranking, Position, Order
- Asian and Pacific Islander: API, Ethnicity, Cultural Group
- Count: Frequency, Number of Occurrences, Registration Count
- Naming Trends: Name Popularity, Name Fashions, Naming Conventions

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyzing naming trends within the Asian and Pacific Islander community.
- Identifying popular baby names for girls in 2021.
- Comparing name popularity across different ethnic groups (if other datasets are available).
- Developing resources for expectant parents seeking name ideas.
- Studying the cultural significance of names within the API community.

title: Emergency Response Incidents
ufd: This dataset contains information about emergency response incidents. It includes the type of incident (e.g., Utility-Water Main, Fire-2nd Alarm), the location as a street address, and the borough where the incident occurred. The dataset also provides the date and time the incident was created, along with latitude and longitude coordinates. The 'incident_type' column categorizes the emergency, while 'location' and 'borough' specify where it happened. The 'creation_date' indicates when the incident was reported. This data could be used to analyze the types and locations of emergencies, identify trends, and improve resource allocation for emergency services. Note that the 'closed_date' column has mostly missing values.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details emergency response incidents, including the incident type, location (street address and borough), and creation date/time. Latitude and longitude coordinates are also provided for each incident. The data can be used to analyze emergency trends and improve resource allocation.

Related Topics:
- Emergency Management
- Public Health
- Urban Planning
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Incident Type: Emergency Category, Event Type, Call Type
- Location: Address, Street, Borough, Coordinates, Geo-location
- Creation Date: Incident Date, Report Date, Time of Incident
- Emergency Response: First Responders, Public Safety, Crisis Management

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the frequency and distribution of different types of emergencies.
- Identify high-risk areas for specific incidents based on location data.
- Optimize emergency response times by analyzing historical incident data.
- Visualize incident patterns on a map using latitude and longitude coordinates.
- Predict future emergency hotspots based on historical trends.

title: Street Closures due to construction activities by Block
ufd: This dataset provides information on street closures in New York City due to construction activities. It includes the location of the street closure as a geographic feature (`the_geom`), the street name where the closure occurs (`onstreetname`), and the intersecting streets that define the closed segment (`fromstreetname`, `tostreetname`). The dataset also specifies the borough (`borough_code`) where the closure is located. Key temporal information includes the start and end dates of the work causing the closure (`work_start_date`, `work_end_date`). The `purpose` column describes the type of construction activity taking place. This data can be used to understand the impact of construction on traffic flow, plan alternative routes, or analyze the frequency and duration of street closures in different boroughs. The `segmentid` and `uniqueid` columns can be used to uniquely identify each street closure segment.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details street closures in New York City resulting from construction. It includes geographic location, street names (closed street and intersecting streets), borough, start and end dates of the work, and the purpose of the construction. The data allows for analysis of construction impact on traffic and street closure patterns.

Related Topics:
- Road closures
- Construction
- Traffic management
- Urban planning
- New York City
- Transportation infrastructure

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Street closure: road closure, street obstruction, road blockage
- Construction: work, maintenance, repair, infrastructure project
- Street name: onstreetname, fromstreetname, tostreetname
- Borough: NYC borough, county
- Work start date: start date, begin date
- Work end date: end date, completion date
- Purpose: construction type, activity, reason for closure

Applications and Use Cases:
- Traffic rerouting and navigation app development
- Analysis of construction impact on local businesses
- Urban planning and infrastructure management
- Prediction of future street closures based on historical data
- Identification of high-impact construction zones

title: Motor Vehicle Collisions - Vehicles
ufd: This dataset contains information about motor vehicle collisions in NYC, with each row representing a vehicle involved in a crash. Key details include the crash date and time, the type of vehicle, and the state registration. You can also find contributing factors to the collision. The dataset provides a unique ID for each vehicle and the corresponding collision ID. This data could be used to analyze trends in vehicle collisions, identify common contributing factors, or assess the types of vehicles most frequently involved in accidents. The 'travel_direction', 'pre_crash', and 'point_of_impact' columns offer insights into the circumstances surrounding the collisions. Note that some columns, such as vehicle make and year, have a high percentage of missing values.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details motor vehicle collisions in New York City, with each record representing a vehicle involved in a crash. It includes information on the crash date and time, vehicle type, state registration, and contributing factors. Unique identifiers for both the vehicle and the collision are provided.

Related Topics:
- Traffic Safety
- Accident Analysis
- Urban Planning
- Vehicle Safety
- New York City

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Motor Vehicle Collision: Car accident, traffic collision, vehicle crash, auto accident
- Contributing Factors: Cause of accident, reasons for collision, factors leading to crash
- Vehicle Type: Car model, vehicle make, type of vehicle
- State Registration: License plate state, vehicle registration state

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in vehicle collisions over time.

- Improve traffic safety policies and infrastructure planning.

title: DOB Certificate Of Occupancy
ufd: This dataset contains information on Certificates of Occupancy (CO) issued by the New York City Department of Buildings (DOB) from July 2012 to March 2021. A Certificate of Occupancy states a building’s legal use and type of permitted occupancy. Each row represents a specific CO, identified by a unique job number. Key details include the job type (e.g., A1 or NB), the date the CO was issued, the borough where the property is located, and the building identification number (BIN). You can also find the house number, street name, block, lot, and postcode for the property. This dataset could be used to analyze trends in building occupancy, assess housing development patterns across different boroughs, or examine the timeline of CO issuances for specific properties. The dataset also includes geographic information such as latitude, longitude, community board, council district, and census tract.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details Certificates of Occupancy (CO) issued by the NYC DOB from July 2012 to March 2021. Each record represents a unique CO, identified by job number, and includes information on the property's legal use, occupancy type, location, and issuance date. The data spans all five boroughs and includes geographic identifiers like latitude, longitude, and census tract.

Related Topics:
- Real Estate
- Urban Planning

- Borough: NYC borough (Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx, Staten Island)

Applications and Use Cases:

- Identify properties with specific occupancy types in particular neighborhoods.
- Examine the relationship between CO issuance dates and other property characteristics.
- Investigate the geographic distribution of new construction and renovations.
- Predict future housing development based on historical CO issuance patterns.

title: New York City Population By Community Districts
ufd: This dataset contains population figures for New York City community districts from 1970 to 2010, collected from the Census Bureau. Each row represents a community district, identified by its borough (e.g., Bronx, Brooklyn), a community district number, and a descriptive name. The dataset includes population counts for each district for the census years 1970, 1980, 1990, 2000, and 2010. This data can be used to analyze population trends and demographic changes within different community districts over time. Researchers, city planners, and policymakers can leverage this information for urban development, resource allocation, and understanding the evolving needs of different neighborhoods. The data was compiled by the Population Division of the New York City Department of City Planning.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides population data for New York City community districts from 1970 to 2010, sourced from the Census Bureau. It includes population counts for each district across five census years: 1970, 1980, 1990, 2000, and 2010. The data is organized by borough, community district number, and community district name, enabling analysis of population trends within specific areas of New York City.

- Study demographic shifts within community districts over time.

title: Water Consumption in the City of New York
ufd: This dataset provides a historical record of water consumption in New York City, offering insights into the city's water usage patterns over time. It includes data from 1960 to 2024, detailing the city's population, total water consumption in millions of gallons per day, and per capita water consumption. The 'year' column indicates the year of the data, while 'new_york_city_population' represents the population count for that year. 'nyc_consumption_million_gallons_per_day' shows the total water consumed, and 'per_capita_gallons_per_person_per_day' calculates the average water usage per person. Researchers, urban planners, and environmental scientists can use this data to analyze trends in water consumption, understand the relationship between population and water demand, and develop strategies for sustainable water management in urban environments. The dataset can also be used to forecast future water needs and assess the impact of conservation efforts.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains historical water consumption data for New York City from 1960 to 2024. It includes yearly population figures, total water consumption in millions of gallons per day, and per capita water consumption. This data allows for analysis of water usage trends and the relationship between population and water demand in NYC.

Related Topics:
  - Water Resources
  - Urban Planning
  - Environmental Science
  - Population Studies
  - Sustainability
  - New York City

  - Population: Demographics, inhabitants, residents
  - Per Capita Consumption: Water use per person, average daily use

  - New York City: NYC, Manhattan, urban area

Applications and Use Cases:

  - Evaluate the effectiveness of water conservation programs.
  - Study the relationship between population density and water usage.
  - Compare NYC water consumption patterns to other major cities.
  - Develop strategies for sustainable water management in urban environments.

title: NYPD Hate Crimes
ufd: This dataset contains records of confirmed hate crimes in New York City. Each row represents a single complaint, identified by a unique `full_complaint_id`. The data includes the year and month of the complaint (`complaint_year_number`, `month_number`), as well as the date the record was created (`record_create_date`). Location information is provided through the `complaint_precinct_code`, `patrol_borough_name`, and `county` columns. Details about the offense are captured in columns like `law_code_category_description`, `offense_description`, and `pd_code_description`. The `bias_motive_description` column specifies the motive behind the hate crime, and `offense_category` provides a general classification of the crime. This dataset could be used to analyze trends in hate crimes over time and across different locations in NYC, understand the types of offenses being committed, and identify the motivations behind these crimes. The dataset is limited to Anti-Jewish hate crimes in Brooklyn South.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details confirmed Anti-Jewish hate crimes reported in Brooklyn South, New York City. Each record represents a single complaint and includes information on the date, location (precinct, borough, county), offense details (law code, offense description, PD code), bias motive, and offense category. The data spans multiple years and can be used to analyze trends and patterns in Anti-Jewish hate crimes within Brooklyn South.

Related Topics:

- Bias Motive: Motivation, prejudice, underlying cause
- Complaint Precinct Code: Police precinct, district

title: CURRENT BASES
ufd: This dataset provides information on current For-Hire Vehicle (FHV) bases in New York City. Each row represents a unique base and includes details such as the license number, entity name, telephone number, and physical address (building, street, city, state, and zip code). The `type_of_base` column specifies the type of service offered, such as "Livery Base," "Black Car Base," or "Luxury/Limousine." Location data is also provided in the form of latitude and longitude coordinates. The dataset also includes computed region identifiers. You can use this dataset to identify and locate FHV bases, analyze their distribution across the city, or examine the prevalence of different base types. Note that the dataset provides a link to the official NYC website for the most up-to-date information.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information about For-Hire Vehicle (FHV) bases operating in New York City. It includes details on each base's license, name, contact information, address, and geographic coordinates. The dataset also specifies the type of service offered by each base (e.g., Livery, Black Car).

Related Topics:

- For-Hire Vehicles
- Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC)

Applications and Use Cases:

title: Recent Contract Awards
ufd: This dataset contains information on recent contract awards by New York City agencies. It's a record of the City's procurement activities, managed by the Office of Citywide Procurement. Key details include the agency making the award (`agency_name`), the type and category of service or goods being contracted (`type_of_notice_description`, `category_description`), and a brief description of the contract (`short_title`). The dataset also provides the start and end dates of the award, the method used for selecting the vendor (`selection_method_description`), and the contract amount (`contract_amount`). You can use this data to understand which agencies are awarding contracts, the types of services being procured, and the monetary value of these contracts. Contact information for each award, such as contact name and email, is also provided. This information can be valuable for businesses seeking to work with the City, as well as for citizens interested in government spending and procurement practices.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details recent contract awards made by New York City agencies, documenting the city's procurement activities. It includes information on the awarding agency, the type of goods or services contracted, contract dates, and the contract amount. The data also contains vendor selection methods and contact information for each award.

title: Fire Incident Dispatch Data
ufd: This dataset contains information about fire incidents in New York City, as recorded by the Starfire Computer Aided Dispatch System. Each row represents a unique incident, identified by a `starfire_incident_id`, and includes the date and time the incident occurred (`incident_datetime`). The data provides details on the location of the incident, including the `alarm_box_borough`, `alarm_box_number`, and `alarm_box_location`, as well as broader geographic information like `zipcode`, `policeprecinct`, and `citycouncildistrict`. You can explore the nature of the incidents through the `incident_classification` and `incident_classification_group` columns, and understand the severity using `alarm_level_index_description` and `highest_alarm_level`. The dataset also tracks response times, such as `dispatch_response_seconds_qy` and `incident_response_seconds_qy`, along with the number of engines, ladders, and other units assigned. Researchers and public safety analysts can use this data to analyze incident patterns, evaluate response times, and optimize resource allocation. The data spans from incident creation to closure, offering a comprehensive view of the Fire Department's response to emergencies.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details fire incidents in New York City, captured by the Starfire Computer Aided Dispatch System. Each record represents a unique incident, providing information on location, incident type, alarm levels, and response times. The data allows for analysis of incident patterns, response effectiveness, and resource allocation within the Fire Department.

Related Topics:

- Alarm Level: Severity, priority, escalation

- Location: Address, borough, zip code, geographic coordinates

Applications and Use Cases:

- Optimize resource allocation by understanding the demand for fire services in different areas.
- Develop predictive models to forecast fire risk based on location, time of year, and other factors.
- Support urban planning and infrastructure development by identifying areas with high fire incident rates.
- Assess the impact of fire safety regulations and public awareness campaigns.

title: COVID-19 Daily Counts of Cases, Hospitalizations, and Deaths
ufd: This dataset provides daily COVID-19 statistics for New York City residents. It includes the daily counts of positive cases (both confirmed and probable), hospitalizations, and deaths. You can also find the 7-day averages for these metrics, offering a smoothed view of trends. The data is broken down by borough (Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens, and Staten Island), allowing for granular analysis of the pandemic's impact across the city. The `date_of_interest` column indicates the day for which the data is reported. Researchers and public health officials can use this dataset to track the spread of COVID-19, assess the effectiveness of interventions, and understand the burden on the healthcare system.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains daily COVID-19 statistics for New York City, broken down by borough. It includes daily counts and 7-day averages for positive cases (confirmed and probable), hospitalizations, and deaths. The data allows for tracking the pandemic's impact across different areas of the city over time.

  - 7-Day Average: Rolling Average, Moving Average, Trend Line

Applications and Use Cases:

  - Analyze trends in hospitalizations and deaths related to COVID-19.
  - Evaluate the effectiveness of public health interventions.
  - Compare the impact of COVID-19 across different boroughs.
  - Forecast future case numbers and hospitalizations.

title: Property Tax Rates by Tax Class
ufd: This dataset provides a table of property tax rates by tax class for a city government. It includes tax rates for four different classes of property (class_1, class_2, class_3, and class_4) across different years. The 'year' column indicates the tax year for which the rates apply. Each of the class columns (class_1 through class_4) represents the tax rate for that specific property class. This dataset could be used to analyze trends in property tax rates over time for different property types. City planners, residents, or real estate professionals might find this information useful for understanding the local tax landscape. The dataset contains 28 rows, spanning different tax years.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains property tax rates for a city government, broken down by property class (class_1, class_2, class_3, class_4) and year. It provides a historical view of tax rates for different property types. The data spans multiple years and allows for analysis of tax rate trends.

Applications and Use Cases:

- Compare tax rates across different property classes.
- Forecast future property tax revenues.
- Inform property investment decisions.
- Evaluate the impact of tax policies on different property types.

title: Sidewalk Management Database - Violations
ufd: This dataset contains information on sidewalk violations in New York City, managed through the Sidewalk Management System. It tracks inspections, violations, and the status of sidewalks. Key columns include `violationid`, a unique identifier for each violation, and address information split across columns like `house_num`, `frstname` (street name from), and `tostname` (street name to). Several date fields are present, such as `vissuedate` (violation issued date), `certi_date` (certification date), `vdismissdate` (violation dismissal date), `post_date` (posting date) and `entrydate` (date of entry). The dataset also includes flags indicating specific sidewalk defects like `broken` sidewalks or `trip_haz`ards. The `contract` column identifies the contract associated with the violation. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze sidewalk conditions, track violation trends, and improve sidewalk maintenance strategies.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details sidewalk violations recorded in New York City through the Sidewalk Management System. It includes information on inspections, violations issued, and sidewalk status. Key details include violation IDs, address information, various dates related to the violation lifecycle, and flags indicating specific sidewalk defects.

- Track the lifecycle of sidewalk violations from issuance to resolution.

title: Parking Meters Locations and Status
ufd: This dataset provides information on the locations and status of parking meters in New York City. Each record represents a single parking meter and includes details such as its meter number, current status (active or inactive), and pay-by-cell number. The dataset also specifies the hours of operation for each meter, the type of facility (on-street or off-street), and the borough in which it is located. Location information is provided through street names, side of the street, intersecting streets, latitude, and longitude. Computed regions are also included for more granular geographic analysis. This data can be used to analyze parking availability, identify areas with high meter utilization, or investigate parking meter issues.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the locations, operational status, and characteristics of parking meters throughout New York City. It includes attributes like meter ID, status (active/inactive), payment options, operational hours, and location details. Location information is provided through street addresses, coordinates, and computed regions.

title: Property Valuation and Assessment Data Tax Classes 1,2,3,4
ufd: This dataset contains property valuation and assessment data for New York City, specifically focusing on tax classes 1, 2, 3, and 4. It includes information used to calculate property taxes and grant exemptions or abatements. Key columns include `boro` (borough), `block`, `lot`, `year` (assessment year), `pymktland` (previous year market land value), `pymkttot` (previous year total market value), and `pytaxclass` (previous year tax class). The dataset also provides details on building class (`bldg_class`), owner, and zoning. Researchers, city planners, and real estate professionals can use this data to analyze property values, understand tax burdens, and assess property characteristics across the city. The data is collected and entered by various city employees, including property assessors and exemption specialists.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed property valuation and assessment information for New York City, covering tax classes 1 through 4. It includes data on market values, tax classes, building characteristics, and ownership details. title: 2020 Census Tracts
ufd: This dataset contains geographic and demographic information for the 2020 Census Tracts in New York City. It includes the geometry of each census tract, represented in the `the_geom` column, allowing for spatial analysis and mapping. Key columns include `ctlabel` and `ct2020`, which are identifiers for the census tract. The dataset also provides the borough code (`borocode`) and borough name (`boroname`) for each tract, along with neighborhood information in the `ntaname` and `nta2020` columns. Community district information is available in the `cdta2020` and `cdtaname` columns. Researchers, city planners, and the public can use this dataset to analyze population distribution, understand neighborhood characteristics, and support decision-making related to resource allocation and urban development within New York City. The `cdeligibil` column indicates eligibility, potentially for specific programs or funding.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides geographic and demographic details for the 2020 Census Tracts in New York City. title: NYC Permitted Event Information
ufd: This dataset provides information on permitted events in New York City, offering a glimpse into the city's vibrant event landscape. Each row represents a specific event, identified by a unique `event_id` and described by its `event_name`. The dataset includes the `start_date_time` and `end_date_time` of the event, as well as the `event_agency` responsible for the event. You can find out what type of event it is via the `event_type` column (e.g., "Sport - Youth", "Special Event", "Farmers Market"). The `event_borough` and `event_location` columns specify where the event is taking place. Additional details include the `community_board` and `police_precinct` associated with the event. This dataset could be used to analyze event trends across different boroughs, understand the types of events that occur most frequently, or plan resources based on event schedules and locations.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details permitted events within New York City, offering a comprehensive view of the city's event activity. It includes information on event names, dates, times, locations, responsible agencies, and event types. The data spans various boroughs and provides insights into the frequency and distribution of different event categories.

title: Rodent Inspection
ufd: This dataset contains information about rodent inspections conducted in New York City. Each row represents a single inspection, detailing the location, type of inspection, and the result. Key columns include `inspection_type`, indicating whether it was an initial inspection, a follow-up ("BAIT"), or a compliance check, and `result`, which shows whether the inspection passed or indicated rat activity. Location information is provided through address components like `house_number`, `street_name`, `borough`, and `zip_code`, as well as geographic coordinates. The `job_progress` column tracks the status of the inspection job. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to analyze rat activity patterns across the city, evaluate the effectiveness of pest control measures, and identify areas with the greatest need for intervention. The data also includes several computed region columns that provide additional geographic context.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed records of rodent inspections performed in New York City. Each entry includes information on the inspection type (initial, follow-up, compliance), result (pass/fail indicating rat activity), and precise location details. The data can be used to understand and address rodent issues across the city.

Related Topics:

title: Parking Regulation Locations and Signs
ufd: This dataset contains information about parking regulation signs managed by the New York City Department of Transportation. It includes details on the location of these signs, such as the borough, street names, and side of the street. Key columns include `order_number` to identify specific orders, `sign_code` and `sign_description` to understand the parking regulation, and `order_completed_on_date` to track when the sign was installed or updated. The dataset also provides the size of the sign (`sign_size`) and its distance from the nearest intersection. Researchers, city planners, and residents can use this dataset to analyze parking regulations, identify areas with specific signage, and track changes in parking policies over time. The geographic coordinates (`sign_x_coord`, `sign_y_coord`) allow for spatial analysis and mapping of parking regulations.
sfd:

It includes information on sign location (borough, street, coordinates), sign details (code, description, size), and installation dates. title: TLC New Driver Application Status
ufd: This dataset provides the status of new TLC (Taxi and Limousine Commission) driver license applications. Updated frequently, it allows applicants to check the progress of their application. Key columns include the application number (`app_no`), the application date (`app_date`), and the current status (`status`), indicating whether the application is incomplete, approved, denied, or under review. The dataset also tracks the completion status of required items such as the drug test, WAV course, defensive driving course, driver exam, and medical clearance form. Additional requirements, like fingerprints or a copy of the DMV license, are listed in the `other_requirements` column. The `lastupdate` column shows the timestamp of the last update to the dataset. Users can leverage this data to monitor their application's progress and identify any outstanding requirements. This dataset focuses solely on "HDR" type applications.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on the status of new Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC) driver license applications, specifically "HDR" type applications. It provides details on application progress, required documents, and the latest update timestamp. Users can track the status of their application and identify any outstanding requirements.

Related Topics:

title: Property Exemption Detail
ufd: This dataset provides detailed information on property tax exemptions in New York City, as maintained by the Department of Finance. It covers exemptions for government, not-for-profit, and commercial properties. Key columns include `boro` (borough), `block`, and `lot`, which together uniquely identify a property. The `exmp_code` and `nys_exmp_code` columns specify the type of exemption applied to the property, while columns like `pyexmptot`, `tenexmptot`, and `curexmptot` detail the total exemption amounts for previous, current, and cured tax years, respectively. Researchers, city planners, and property owners can use this data to analyze trends in property tax exemptions, assess the fiscal impact of these exemptions, and understand the distribution of benefits across different property types and boroughs. The `exname` column provides the name of the exempt entity. The dataset includes information from 2024 and earlier.

title: DHS Daily Report
ufd: This dataset provides a daily snapshot of the number of individuals and families residing in Department of Homeless Services (DHS) shelters. The dataset includes a daily census date, along with counts of total adults, children, and individuals in shelters. It further breaks down the adult population into single men and women, and provides counts of families with children, including the number of adults and children within those families. Researchers and policy makers can use this data to analyze trends in shelter populations, understand the composition of individuals and families seeking shelter, and inform resource allocation strategies. The dataset contains 100 rows with data from late 2025. Key metrics include `total_adults_in_shelter`, `total_children_in_shelter`, and `families_with_children_in_shelter`.
sfd:

title: Street Construction Permits (2022-Present)
ufd: This dataset contains information on street construction permits issued by the DOT from 2022 to the present. Each row represents a unique permit, identified by its `permitnumber` and `applicationtrackingid`. Key details include the type of permit (`permitseriesshortdesc`, `permittypedesc`), its status (`permitstatusshortdesc`), and the dates it was issued and valid (`permitissuedate`, `issuedworkstartdate`, `issuedworkenddate`). The data also provides location information, including the borough (`boroughname`) and street names (`onstreetname`, `fromstreetname`, `tostreetname`). The `permitteename` column indicates the organization or individual who was granted the permit. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze construction activity, track permit trends, and assess the impact of construction on city streets and infrastructure. The `specificstipulations` column may contain additional conditions or requirements associated with the permit.
sfd:

title: Bus Breakdown and Delays
ufd: This dataset provides real-time information about NYC school bus breakdowns and delays, as reported by bus vendors. It includes details such as the school year, bus number, route, and reason for the delay (e.g., heavy traffic, mechanical problems). The `run_type` column specifies whether the bus run is for general education, special education, or pre-K/early intervention. Key columns also indicate whether schools and parents were notified and if the Office of Pupil Transportation (OPT) was alerted. You can use this data to analyze trends in bus delays, identify common reasons for breakdowns, and assess the effectiveness of communication protocols. The `occurred_on` and `created_on` columns provide timestamps for when the delay occurred and when it was reported. The dataset also includes the bus company name, the number of students on the bus, and the borough where the incident occurred.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains real-time information on NYC school bus breakdowns and delays, as reported by bus vendors. It includes details about the bus route, reason for delay, school year, and notification status. The data can be used to analyze delay trends, identify common causes, and assess communication effectiveness.

Related Topics:
- School Transportation
- Public Transportation
- Urban Planning
- Education
- Data Analysis
- Real-Time Data
- Incident Reporting

Concepts and Synonyms:
- School Bus Delays: Bus Breakdowns, Transportation Disruptions, Late Buses
- Bus Route: Route Number, Trip ID
- Reason for Delay: Mechanical Issues, Traffic Congestion, Accident, Weather
- Notification Status: Parent Notification, School Notification, OPT Alert
- Run Type: General Education, Special Education, Pre-K/Early Intervention

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in school bus delays over time.
- Identify the most common reasons for bus breakdowns and delays.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of communication protocols for notifying parents and schools.
- Optimize bus routes to minimize delays.
- Predict potential bus delays based on weather conditions or traffic patterns.
- Assess the performance of different bus vendors.
- Improve resource allocation for bus maintenance and repairs.

title: Motor Vehicle Collisions - Person
ufd: This dataset contains information about people involved in motor vehicle collisions in New York City, starting from April 2016. Each row represents a person involved in a crash, detailing their role (driver, occupant, pedestrian, or bicyclist), any injuries sustained, and demographic information like age and sex. Key columns include `crash_date` and `crash_time` for when the incident occurred, `person_type` to identify the person's role, and `person_injury` to describe the extent of injuries. The dataset also includes details about the vehicle involved (`vehicle_id`) and contributing factors to the crash. Researchers and public safety analysts can use this data to identify trends in traffic accidents, understand factors contributing to injuries, and develop strategies for improving road safety. The data can also be used to analyze the effectiveness of safety equipment and identify high-risk populations or locations.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed information on individuals involved in motor vehicle collisions in New York City, beginning in April 2016. It includes data on the person's role in the crash (driver, pedestrian, etc.), injuries sustained, and demographic characteristics. The dataset also contains information about the vehicles involved and contributing factors to the accidents.

Related Topics:

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Motor Vehicle Collision: Car accident, traffic crash, vehicle incident
- Person Type: Driver, pedestrian, cyclist, occupant, passenger
- Person Injury: Injury severity, injuries sustained, physical harm
- Contributing Factors: Cause of accident, accident factors, reasons for crash
- Crash Date/Time: Accident date, incident time, collision timestamp

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in traffic accidents and identify high-risk locations.
- Understand factors contributing to injuries and fatalities in vehicle collisions.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of safety equipment and regulations.
- Develop targeted interventions to improve road safety for specific populations (e.g., pedestrians, cyclists).
- Identify patterns in driver behavior and contributing factors to accidents.
- Analyze the impact of infrastructure changes on traffic safety.

title: New York City Population By Neighborhood Tabulation Areas
ufd: This dataset provides population figures for New York City, broken down by Neighborhood Tabulation Areas (NTAs). NTAs are aggregations of census tracts and subsets of Public Use Microdata Areas, and may not perfectly represent neighborhoods. The data originates from the Census Bureau's Decennial data. Each row represents a specific NTA in the year 2000. Key columns include 'borough' indicating the borough the NTA is located in, 'nta_code' and 'nta_name' which provide a unique identifier and name for each neighborhood tabulation area, and 'population' which gives the population count for that area. The 'fips_county_code' column provides the FIPS code for the county. This dataset could be used to analyze population distribution across NYC neighborhoods, compare population sizes between different areas, or as a basis for further demographic studies.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset contains population figures for New York City at the Neighborhood Tabulation Area (NTA) level for the year 2000. NTAs are statistical areas created from aggregations of census tracts. The data includes borough, NTA code and name, population count, and FIPS county code for each NTA.

**Related Topics:**
- Demographics
- Urban Planning
- Census Data
- Geographic Data
- New York City

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- Neighborhood Tabulation Area (NTA)
- Population Count
- Census Tract
- Borough
- FIPS Code
- NYC Neighborhoods

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Analyzing population distribution across NYC neighborhoods.
- Comparing population sizes between different NTAs.
- Serving as a basis for demographic studies and urban planning initiatives.
- Mapping population density in New York City.
- Combining with other datasets for socio-economic analysis at the neighborhood level.

title: Forestry Tree Points
ufd: This dataset contains records of forestry tree points managed by NYC Parks & Recreation. Each row represents a tree, identified by a unique `objectid` and `globalid`, and includes its location as a point (`geometry`). Key attributes include `genusspecies` which specifies the tree's species, `dbh` (diameter at breast height) indicating the tree's size, `tpstructure` describing the tree's structure (e.g., Full, Retired, Stump), and `tpcondition` assessing the tree's health (e.g., Excellent, Good, Poor, Dead). The dataset also provides information on planting spaces (`plantingspaceglobalid`) and administrative regions. Users can analyze tree distribution, health trends, and species diversity across different areas of NYC. This data can be joined with the Forestry Planting Spaces dataset using `plantingspaceglobalid` to gain a comprehensive view of tree management. The `riskrating` and `riskratingdate` columns provide insights into tree risk assessments.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details individual trees managed by NYC Parks & Recreation, providing location, species, size, and condition information for each tree. It includes attributes like species (`genusspecies`), diameter (`dbh`), structure (`tpstructure`), and health (`tpcondition`). The data also contains risk assessment information and can be linked to planting space data for a more comprehensive view of tree management.

Related Topics:
- Urban Forestry
- Tree Management
- Urban Ecology
- NYC Parks
- Environmental Monitoring
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Tree Inventory: Tree census, tree registry, urban forest inventory
- Genus Species: Tree species, botanical name, scientific name
- DBH (Diameter at Breast Height): Tree size, trunk diameter
- TP Structure: Tree structure, tree form, growth habit
- TP Condition: Tree health, tree status, tree vigor
- Planting Space: Tree bed, planting location, planting site
- Risk Rating: Tree hazard assessment, risk evaluation

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze tree species distribution across NYC.
- Assess the health and condition of trees in different parks.
- Identify areas with high tree risk ratings.
- Map tree locations and visualize tree characteristics.
- Study the relationship between tree size and environmental factors.
- Combine with planting space data to evaluate planting success.
- Track changes in tree populations over time.

title: Bedbug Reporting
ufd: This dataset contains information on bed bug infestation history in New York City properties, as reported annually by property owners. It includes details such as the building's address (borough, house number, street name, and postcode), the number of dwelling units, and counts of infested, eradicated, and re-infested units. The filing date and the period the filing covers are also included. You can use this data to analyze trends in bed bug infestations across different boroughs, identify areas with high infestation rates, and track the effectiveness of eradication efforts. The dataset also provides location information through latitude, longitude, community board, city council district, and neighborhood (NTA), enabling spatial analysis of bed bug incidents. Each record represents a filing completed by a property owner, with the most recent filing considered the active submission for a given period.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the history of bed bug infestations in New York City properties, as reported annually by property owners. It includes information on property addresses, dwelling unit counts, and infestation statistics (infested, eradicated, and re-infested units). The data also offers location details like borough, latitude, longitude, and community board, allowing for spatial analysis of bed bug incidents.

- Infestation Status: Eradicated, Re-infested, Active Infestation
- Location: Borough, Address, Latitude, Longitude, Community Board, NTA (Neighborhood Tabulation Area), City Council District

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in bed bug infestations across NYC boroughs.
- Identify areas with high bed bug infestation rates.
- Track the effectiveness of bed bug eradication efforts.
- Develop targeted pest control strategies.
- Inform public health initiatives related to pest control.
- Assist property managers in addressing bed bug issues.
- Conduct spatial analysis of bed bug incidents using location data.
- Investigate correlations between housing characteristics and infestation rates.

title: NYC Dog Licensing Dataset
ufd: This dataset contains information on active dog licenses in New York City. It includes details such as the dog's name, gender, breed, and birth year. The dataset also provides the zipcode where the dog resides, the date the license was issued, and the license expiration date. The `extract_year` column indicates the year the data was extracted. This data could be used to analyze dog populations by breed and location within NYC. It could also be used to study trends in dog licensing and identify areas with low compliance rates.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides details on active dog licenses in New York City. It includes information on dog characteristics like name, gender, breed, and birth year, as well as license details such as issue and expiration dates. The data also contains location information via zipcode and the year the data was extracted.

title: Electric Consumption And Cost (2010 - May 2025)
ufd: This dataset contains monthly electric consumption and cost information for various developments in New York City, spanning from 2010 to May 2025. The data is broken down by borough and development name, allowing users to analyze energy usage patterns in specific areas. Key columns include `consumption_kwh` (kilowatt-hour consumption), `current_charges` (billing charges), `vendor_name` (utility provider), and `funding_source`. The dataset also provides details on meter types (`meter_amr`) and billing IDs (`umis_bill_id`). Researchers and city planners can use this data to understand energy consumption trends, identify areas with high energy costs, and assess the impact of different funding sources on energy efficiency in housing developments. The `revenue_month`, `service_start_date`, and `service_end_date` columns enable time-series analysis of energy consumption.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides monthly electricity consumption and cost details for New York City housing developments from 2010 to May 2025. It includes data on energy usage (kWh), billing charges, utility providers, and funding sources, categorized by borough and development. The dataset enables analysis of energy consumption trends and cost variations across different developments.

- Predict future energy consumption based on historical data.

title: Public Restrooms
ufd: This dataset provides information on public restrooms in New York City, including those in parks and libraries. You can find details such as the facility name, location type (e.g., park, library), and the operating organization. The dataset also indicates the current operational status, availability of changing stations, and accessibility information. Location is specified by latitude and longitude coordinates. Furthermore, you can find details on hours of operation and restroom types (e.g., multi-stall, single-stall all-gender). This information can be used to locate public restrooms, check their accessibility, and determine their hours. Keep in mind that restroom availability may change due to maintenance or other factors.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information about public restrooms in New York City, including those located in parks and libraries. title: Multiple Dwelling Registrations
ufd: This dataset contains registration information for multiple dwelling units in New York City, specifically focusing on Manhattan in this sample. Collected by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD), it includes details about residential rental buildings with three or more units, or one- or two-family homes not occupied by the owner or their family. Key columns include `housenumber`, `streetname`, `zip`, `boro` (borough), `communityboard`, `lastregistrationdate`, and `registrationenddate`. The dataset also provides unique identifiers for each registration (`registrationid`) and building (`buildingid`). Researchers, urban planners, and real estate professionals can use this data to analyze housing trends, track building registration compliance, and understand the distribution of rental properties across Manhattan. The data includes the street code, block, lot, and building identification number (BIN) for precise location analysis.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides registration details for multiple dwelling units in New York City, with a focus on Manhattan. It includes information about residential rental buildings and non-owner-occupied homes, collected by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD). Key details include address information, registration dates, and unique identifiers for buildings and registrations.

title: Harbor Water Quality
ufd: This dataset contains water quality measurements collected from various locations in a harbor. The data includes information on sampling location, date, and time, along with weather conditions at the time of sampling. Key measurements include temperature, salinity, conductivity, dissolved oxygen, pH, and levels of various nutrients and bacteria at both the top and bottom of the water column. The dataset also provides information on water depth, current speed and direction, wind speed and direction, and sea state. Researchers and environmental managers can use this data to assess water quality trends, identify pollution sources, and monitor the health of the harbor ecosystem. The `sampling_location` column identifies where the samples were taken, while `sample_date` and `sample_time` provide the temporal context for the measurements.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides comprehensive water quality measurements collected from a harbor, encompassing various locations and time points. It includes physical, chemical, and biological parameters measured at both the top and bottom of the water column, along with weather and environmental conditions. This data can be used to analyze water quality, track pollution, and assess ecosystem health.

Related Topics:

  - Nutrients: Nitrogen, phosphorus, nitrates, phosphates
  - Bacteria: Coliforms, E. coli, microbial counts

Applications and Use Cases:

  - Develop and validate water quality models.
  - Inform coastal management and conservation efforts.
  - Analyze the relationship between weather conditions and water quality parameters.
  - Track the effectiveness of pollution control measures.

title: 2017-18  - 2021-22 Demographic Snapshot
ufd: This dataset provides a demographic snapshot of New York City public schools from 2017-18 to 2021-22. It includes enrollment counts, broken down by grade level, gender, and race/ethnicity. You can use this data to analyze trends in student demographics over time, identify disparities in enrollment across different groups, and understand the characteristics of students in specific schools. Key columns include 'school_name', 'year', 'total_enrollment', and enrollment counts for various demographic groups. The dataset also contains information on students with disabilities, English language learners, poverty levels, and the Economic Need Index for each school. Note that enrollment counts are based on the October 31 Audited Register, with slight variations in 2020-21 and 2021-22 due to school year delays. Data on students with disabilities, English Language Learners, students' poverty status, and students' Economic Need Value are as of the June 30 for each school year except in 2021-22. Data on SWDs, ELLs, Poverty, and ENI in the 2021-22 school year are as of March 7, 2022.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains demographic information for New York City public schools from the 2017-18 to 2021-22 school years. It provides enrollment counts broken down by grade, gender, and race/ethnicity. The data also includes information on students with disabilities, English language learners, poverty levels, and the Economic Need Index for each school.

title: Total SNAP Recipients (Historical)
ufd: This dataset provides monthly statistics on the total number of individuals receiving benefits from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP). The dataset includes two columns: 'month', indicating the month for which the data is recorded, and 'total_snap_recipients', representing the total count of SNAP recipients for that month. Each row represents a unique month, with data spanning 100 months. Researchers and policymakers can use this dataset to analyze trends in SNAP participation over time, understand the impact of economic conditions on program enrollment, and inform decisions related to food security and social welfare programs. The data can be used to track changes in the number of SNAP recipients, identify potential areas of need, and evaluate the effectiveness of SNAP in addressing food insecurity.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains monthly statistics on the total number of individuals receiving benefits from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP). It includes the month and the corresponding total number of SNAP recipients for a period of 100 months. This data can be used to analyze trends in SNAP participation and understand the factors influencing program enrollment.

- Assess the effectiveness of SNAP in reducing food insecurity.

title: Civil List
ufd: This dataset provides a snapshot of individuals employed by the City of New York in 2024. It includes details such as the employee's name, the agency they work for (e.g., Police Department, Department of Education), and their salary rate. The 'dpt' column represents the agency code, while 'ttl' refers to the title code associated with the position. 'pc' indicates the pay class of the employee. Researchers or city planners could use this data to analyze salary distributions across different agencies, identify trends in city employment, or gain insights into the workforce composition of various departments. The dataset offers a valuable resource for understanding the financial commitments and personnel structure of New York City's government.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on individuals employed by the City of New York in 2024. It includes details such as employee name, agency, salary rate, agency code, title code, and pay class. This data can be used to analyze salary distributions and workforce composition within New York City government.

title: J-51 Exemption and Abatement (Historical)
ufd: This dataset contains historical information on J-51 property tax exemptions and abatements in New York City, specifically for tax years prior to 2019. The J-51 program provides tax benefits for the renovation of residential apartment buildings. Key columns include 'block' and 'lot' to identify properties, 'tax_year' indicating the year the data applies to, 'cost_of_alt' representing the cost of alterations, and 'abate_grant' showing the amount of the abatement grant.  The 'exempt_amt' column provides the amount of tax exemption. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze the impact of the J-51 program over time, understand trends in property renovation, and assess the distribution of tax benefits across different properties. Note that more recent J-51 data is available in the Property Exemption Detail and Property Abatement Detail datasets.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides historical details on J-51 property tax exemptions and abatements in New York City for tax years before 2019. It includes information on property identifiers (block and lot), tax year, alteration costs, abatement grants, and exemption amounts related to the J-51 program, which incentivizes residential building renovations. This data allows for analysis of the J-51 program's impact and trends in property renovation.

title: Open Restaurant Applications (Historic)
ufd: This dataset contains information on Open Restaurant applications in New York City. It includes details such as restaurant names, addresses (building number, street, borough, and zip code), and the type of seating they are interested in (sidewalk, roadway, or open streets). Key columns include `restaurant_name`, `borough`, `zip`, and `seating_interest_sidewalk`. The dataset also indicates whether the restaurant is approved for sidewalk or roadway seating and if they qualify to serve alcohol. Dimensions of sidewalk and roadway seating areas are provided where applicable. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze the distribution of outdoor dining options across the city, understand the demand for different types of seating, and assess the impact of the Open Restaurants program. The data also includes community board and council district information for further analysis.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details Open Restaurant applications in New York City, providing information on restaurant names, addresses, and seating preferences (sidewalk, roadway, open streets). It includes approval status for sidewalk and roadway seating, alcohol service eligibility, and seating dimensions. The data allows for analysis of outdoor dining distribution and program impact.

title: NYC Historical Vital Records: Index to Digitized Marriage Certificates
ufd: This dataset provides an index to digitized historical marriage certificates from 1866-1937 for all five NYC boroughs. It includes information such as the first and last names of the individuals getting married, along with a soundex code for phonetic matching. The data also specifies the county (primarily Kings county in this sample), the certificate number, and the year, month, and day of the marriage. Researchers, genealogists, and historians can use this dataset to locate and access historical marriage records. The 'number' column likely refers to a unique identifier for each marriage certificate. This dataset can be used to study marriage trends, family history, and demographic changes in New York City.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset indexes digitized historical marriage certificates from New York City spanning 1866 to 1937. It includes names of the married individuals, a soundex code for phonetic matching, and details like county, certificate number, and marriage date. Primarily focused on Kings County, this data enables researchers to locate and access historical marriage records.

Related Topics:

- Marriage Date: Wedding Date, Date of Marriage

title: 2019 Yellow Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip records from yellow taxis, capturing details of individual taxi trips. Each row represents a single trip, including pick-up and drop-off dates/times, locations, and trip distances. Key columns include `tpep_pickup_datetime` and `tpep_dropoff_datetime` for timestamps, `pulocationid` and `dolocationid` for location identifiers, and `trip_distance` for the length of the trip. The dataset also provides information on fares, payment types, and passenger counts. Researchers and analysts can use this data to study taxi ridership patterns, analyze fare structures, or investigate the impact of location on trip characteristics. The `vendorid` column identifies the Technology Service Providers (TSPs) that submitted the trip record. Additionally, the `store_and_fwd_flag` indicates if the trip record was temporarily stored in the vehicle before being sent to the vendor.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed records of individual taxi trips, including pickup and drop-off times, locations, and distances. It encompasses fare information, payment types, and passenger counts for each trip. The data also includes vendor IDs and a flag indicating if the trip record was stored before transmission.

Related Topics:
- Taxi Ridership
