It includes details such as property address, borough, block and lot numbers, owning agency, site area, and suitability for urban agriculture. The data can be used to identify and assess potential locations for community gardens and urban farms.

title: Hotels Properties Citywide
ufd: This dataset provides information on hotel properties in New York City. Each row represents a unique property, identified by its `parid` and `bbl` (Borough, Block, and Lot) number. Key details include the property's address (`street_num`, `street_name`, `postcode`), location (`latitude`, `longitude`), and building classification (`bldg_class`). The data also contains administrative information such as the borough (`borocode`, `borough`), community board (`community_board`), and council district (`council_district`). The `taxyear` indicates the year the tax information is relevant to. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze hotel distribution, property characteristics, and tax information across Manhattan. The dataset could also be used to understand the relationship between hotel properties and their geographic location.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details hotel properties within New York City, offering a comprehensive view of their location, building classification, and administrative details. Each entry is uniquely identified by its property ID and BBL number, encompassing address information, geographic coordinates, and relevant tax year. This resource is valuable for analyzing hotel distribution, property characteristics, and their relationship to geographic location within Manhattan.

title: City Owned and Leased Property (COLP)
ufd: This dataset, known as City Owned and Leased Properties (COLP), provides a comprehensive inventory of properties owned or leased by New York City. It includes details on location, current use, and the responsible city agency. Key columns include `borough` (the borough code where the property is located), `tax_lot` (the tax lot identifier), `agency` (the government agency managing the property), `use_code` and `use_type` (describing the land use), and `non_city_ownership` (indicating if the property is also owned by a non-city entity). Researchers, city planners, and the general public can use this data to understand how city-owned land is being utilized, identify potential areas for development or conservation, and gain insights into the city's real estate portfolio. The dataset is extracted from the Integrated Property Information System (IPIS), maintained by the Department of Citywide Administrative Services (DCAS). This information is mandated for publication by chapter 204 of the City Charter.
sfd:

The City Owned and Leased Properties (COLP) dataset offers a detailed inventory of real estate assets managed by New York City. It includes information on property location, managing agency, land use, and ownership details. This dataset is derived from the Integrated Property Information System (IPIS) and mandated for public release.

title: Mayor's Management Report - Agency Performance Indicators
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the performance of New York City agencies, as tracked in the Mayor's Management Report (MMR). It includes performance indicators organized by agency and their respective goals. Key columns include "agency" and "agency_name," identifying the specific city department responsible for the reported data. The "indicator" column describes the specific metric being tracked, while "goal" outlines the agency's objective related to that indicator. "DesiredDirection" indicates whether the indicator should ideally be trending "Up" or "Down." Researchers, city planners, and residents can use this data to understand how effectively city agencies are meeting their objectives and to track progress over time. The "retired" column indicates whether a particular indicator is no longer actively tracked.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains performance metrics for New York City agencies, as reported in the Mayor's Management Report (MMR). It includes indicators, goals, and desired direction for each agency, allowing users to assess agency performance and track progress. The data also indicates whether an indicator is currently active or retired.

title: Parking Violations Issued - Fiscal Year 2019
ufd: This dataset contains information on parking violations issued in New York City during fiscal year 2019 (July 1, 2018 to June 30, 2019). Each row represents a single parking ticket. Key details include the `summons_number` (unique identifier for the ticket), `plate_id` and `registration_state` of the vehicle, the `issue_date` and `violation_time`, and the `violation_code` explaining the reason for the ticket. The dataset also provides location information via `street_code1`, `street_code2`, `street_code3`, and `street_name`. Researchers and city planners might use this data to analyze parking violation patterns, identify high-violation areas, or assess the effectiveness of parking regulations. Please note that the dataset reflects the status of violations at the time of issuance and may not reflect current status.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

Each record represents a parking ticket, including details like the summons number, vehicle information (plate ID, registration state), violation details (issue date, time, violation code), and location information. The data can be used to analyze parking patterns and assess parking regulations.

title: Recycling Diversion and Capture Rates
ufd: This dataset provides insights into recycling efforts in New York City, specifically focusing on diversion and capture rates within different community districts. It includes data from fiscal year 2019, broken down by fiscal month and month name, allowing for analysis of recycling performance over time. Key metrics include the recycling diversion rate (the percentage of waste recycled instead of being sent to landfills) and capture rates for paper and metal/glass/plastic (MGP), indicating how effectively these materials are being recycled. The data is organized by zone and district, enabling comparisons between different areas of the city. Users can analyze this data to understand recycling trends, identify areas for improvement, and assess the effectiveness of recycling programs. The dataset also includes a combined capture rate metric, offering a comprehensive view of overall recycling success.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains recycling performance data for New York City community districts during fiscal year 2019. It focuses on diversion and capture rates for paper and metal/glass/plastic (MGP) recycling. The data is organized by fiscal month, zone, and district, enabling analysis of recycling trends and comparisons between different areas.

title: NYC Open Data Help Desk: Public Dataset Requests
ufd: This dataset contains a log of public dataset requests submitted to the NYC Open Data team. Each row represents an individual request, identified by a unique `request_id`. The `request` column contains the details of the data being requested, while the `assigned_agency` indicates which city department is responsible for addressing the request. The `response` column provides the Open Data team's reply or action taken. Key dates are also included, such as the `submission_date`, `legislated_due_date`, `data_as_of_date`, and `date_request_closed`, offering a timeline of the request process. Researchers, city planners, and transparency advocates can use this data to understand the types of data the public is interested in, track the responsiveness of city agencies, and identify potential gaps in the city's open data offerings. The `request_status` column indicates whether the request is pending or closed, and if closed, whether it was completed on time.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details public data requests submitted to the NYC Open Data team, providing insights into the types of information sought by the public. Each entry includes the request details, assigned agency, response from the Open Data team, and key dates related to the request's lifecycle. The dataset allows users to track the status of requests and assess the responsiveness of city agencies to public data needs.

Related Topics:
- Open Data

- Public Records Requests
- Government Accountability
- Data Governance

- Data Request: Information Inquiry, Public Data Inquiry, Data Access Request
- Assigned Agency: Responsible Department, City Department, Government Agency
- Request Status: Pending, Closed, Completed, On Time, Overdue
- Open Data Team: City Data Office, Data Management Team
- Submission Date: Request Date, Date Submitted
- Response: Action Taken, Reply, Resolution

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze public interest in specific datasets.
- Evaluate the responsiveness of different city agencies to data requests.
- Identify gaps in the city's open data offerings.
- Track the timeliness of data request fulfillment.
- Understand trends in data requests over time.
- Support research on government transparency and accountability.
- Inform data governance strategies and prioritization.

title: 2020 Yellow Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip records from yellow taxis in 2020. Each row represents a single taxi trip, including details about pick-up and drop-off times and locations, trip distance, and fare information. Key columns include `tpep_pickup_datetime` and `tpep_dropoff_datetime` for timestamps, `pulocationid` and `dolocationid` for pick-up and drop-off locations, and `trip_distance` for the length of the trip. The dataset also provides a breakdown of fares, including `fare_amount`, `extra`, `mta_tax`, `tip_amount`, `tolls_amount`, `improvement_surcharge`, `total_amount`, and `congestion_surcharge`. Additionally, the `payment_type` column indicates how the passenger paid. Researchers and analysts can use this data to study taxi ridership patterns, analyze fare structures, or build predictive models for trip demand.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed records of individual taxi trips in New York City during 2020. It includes information on trip times, locations, distances, fares, and payment types for yellow taxis. The data allows for analysis of taxi usage patterns and fare structures.

Related Topics:
- Transportation
- Urban Planning
- Geospatial Analysis
- Fare Analysis
- Time Series Analysis
- New York City
- Taxi Services

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Taxi trip: ride, journey, cab ride
- Pick-up location: origin, start point, source
- Drop-off location: destination, end point, terminal
- Fare amount: price, cost, charge
- Trip distance: length, mileage
- Payment type: method of payment, payment mode, transaction type
- Ridership patterns: usage trends, demand analysis, traffic flow

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze taxi ridership trends and patterns.
- Predict taxi demand based on time and location.
- Study the impact of congestion pricing on taxi fares.
- Develop models for optimizing taxi dispatch and routing.
- Investigate the relationship between trip distance and fare amount.
- Analyze payment type preferences among taxi passengers.
- Visualize taxi trip data on a map to identify hotspots.

title: Routes by Transportation Sites
ufd: This dataset, titled "Routes by Transportation Sites," connects route information with transportation site details, excluding Pre-K routes. It contains 100 rows of data with three columns. The `school_year` column indicates the academic year the data pertains to, which is uniformly '2015-2016' in this dataset. The `route_number` column provides a unique identifier for each transportation route. The `opt_code` column represents a numeric code, likely a postal code, associated with a specific location. Researchers and transportation planners can use this dataset to analyze route distribution across different locations.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
The "Routes by Transportation Sites" dataset links transportation routes to site-specific details, excluding Pre-K routes. It includes 100 rows of data, focusing on the 2015-2016 school year. Key data points include route numbers and location codes, enabling analysis of route distribution.

**Related Topics:**
- Transportation Planning
- School Bus Routing
- Geographic Data Analysis
- Urban Planning
- Logistics

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- Route Number: Route ID, Transportation Route Identifier
- Opt Code: Postal Code, Location Code, Geographic Identifier
- School Year: Academic Year, Year of Data Collection
- Transportation Sites: Bus Stops, Designated Locations, Pick-up Points

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Analyzing route density in specific geographic areas.
- Identifying potential areas for route optimization.
- Mapping transportation routes based on location codes.
- Studying the relationship between route numbers and transportation sites.

title: Algorithmic Tools Compliance Report
ufd: This dataset contains information on algorithmic tools used by New York City agencies, as reported under Local Law 35. It provides details on tools employing machine learning, AI, or predictive analytics to assist in decision-making that impacts the public. Each row represents a specific tool, including the year it was reported, the agency using it, and a description of its purpose. Key columns include `agency`, indicating the responsible government body, `tool_name`, the name of the algorithmic tool, and `tool_desc`, a detailed explanation of the tool's functionality. Researchers, policymakers, and the public can use this dataset to understand how algorithms are being used within NYC government, assess their potential impact, and ensure compliance with transparency regulations. The data also includes information on the intended purpose of each tool, the data used for training, and the types of data input and output. This information can be used to evaluate the fairness, accuracy, and accountability of these algorithmic systems.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset catalogs algorithmic tools used by New York City agencies, as mandated by Local Law 35. It details tools employing machine learning, AI, or predictive analytics in public-facing decision-making. The data includes information on the agency using the tool, its name, purpose, training data, and input/output data types.

Related Topics:
  - Algorithmic Transparency
  - Artificial Intelligence in Government
  - Machine Learning Applications
  - Predictive Analytics
  - Public Policy
  - Data Governance
  - Local Law 35
  - New York City Government

Concepts and Synonyms:
  - Algorithmic Tool: AI system, predictive model, automated decision-making system
  - Agency: Government department, city office, municipal authority
  - Tool Description: Functionality, purpose, intended use
  - Training Data: Data used for model development, input data
  - Input Data: Data fed into the algorithm, data sources
  - Output Data: Results generated by the algorithm, predictions, scores
  - Local Law 35: NYC algorithmic accountability law, transparency ordinance

Applications and Use Cases:
  - Investigating the types of algorithms used by NYC agencies.
  - Assessing the potential impact of algorithms on public services.
  - Evaluating the fairness and accuracy of algorithmic tools.
  - Monitoring compliance with Local Law 35.
  - Identifying potential biases in algorithmic decision-making.
  - Comparing algorithmic tool usage across different agencies.
  - Analyzing the data sources used to train algorithmic tools.
  - Understanding the intended purpose of each algorithmic tool.

title: DOB Sustainability Compliance Map: Local Law 33
ufd: This dataset provides information on building sustainability compliance in Manhattan, based on Local Law 33 and related data. It includes details such as block and lot numbers, building class, tax class, and the number of buildings at a location. A key feature is the Energy Star score, reflecting a building's energy efficiency, along with a corresponding letter grade. The dataset also contains the gross square footage of buildings. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze building energy performance, identify areas for improvement, and track compliance with sustainability regulations. The data originates from the NYC Department of Finance and the EPA's Portfolio Manager.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on building sustainability compliance in Manhattan, New York City, focusing on Local Law 33. It includes building characteristics like block and lot numbers, building class, tax class, Energy Star scores, letter grades, and gross square footage. The data allows for analysis of building energy performance and compliance with sustainability regulations.

Related Topics:
- Sustainability
- Energy Efficiency

- Building Class: Property type, building classification
- Gross Square Footage: Building size, total area
- Sustainability Compliance: Regulatory adherence, environmental standards

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze building energy performance across Manhattan.
- Identify buildings with low Energy Star scores for targeted interventions.
- Track compliance with Local Law 33 over time.
- Develop policies to improve building sustainability.
- Research the relationship between building characteristics and energy efficiency.

title: NYC Cooling Tower System Inspection Results
ufd: This dataset contains inspection results for cooling tower systems in New York City, conducted by the NYC Health Department. It includes details about the building (address, borough, zip code, and BIN), the cooling system (system ID, status, and number of active equipment), and the inspection itself (date and type). The dataset also provides information on violations, including the violation code, the relevant law section, and a description of the violation. If a violation leads to a summons, the summons number is included. This data can be used to understand compliance with cooling tower regulations, identify potential public health risks, and track enforcement actions. Researchers and public health officials can analyze this data to identify trends in violations and assess the effectiveness of regulatory interventions.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides inspection results for cooling tower systems in New York City, as recorded by the NYC Health Department. It includes details on building information, cooling system specifics, inspection details, and any associated violations. The dataset also tracks summonses issued due to violations, offering a comprehensive view of cooling tower regulation and enforcement.

Related Topics:
- Public Health
- Environmental Health
- Building Inspections
- Regulatory Compliance
- New York City
- Disease Prevention
- Legionella
- Water Management

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Cooling Tower Inspections: Cooling tower assessments, inspection reports, compliance checks
- Violations: Infractions, non-compliance, deficiencies, regulatory breaches
- Summons: Ticket, citation, legal notice, court appearance
- Cooling Tower Systems: Water cooling towers, industrial cooling systems, HVAC cooling
- NYC Health Department: Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH), public health agency

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identify buildings with recurring cooling tower violations.
- Analyze trends in violation types across different boroughs.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of cooling tower regulations in reducing public health risks.
- Predict potential Legionella outbreaks based on inspection data.
- Track the time between violation issuance and summons.
- Assess the compliance rates of cooling tower systems in specific zip codes.

title: Zoning Application Portal (ZAP) - Project Data
ufd: This dataset contains information on land use applications processed by the NYC Department of City Planning (DCP), covering projects from the late 1970s to the present. Each row represents a specific project, identified by a unique `project_id` and described by its `project_name` and `project_brief`. Key columns include `project_status` and `public_status`, indicating the current stage of the application. The `ulurp_non` column specifies whether the project is subject to the Uniform Land Use Review Procedure (ULURP). The dataset also provides details on the `primary_applicant`, their `applicant_type`, and the `borough` where the project is located. Researchers, city planners, and developers can use this dataset to track land use trends, understand the application process, and identify development opportunities in New York City. You can explore projects in the Zoning Application Portal.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details land use applications processed by the NYC Department of City Planning (DCP) from the late 1970s to the present. It includes information on project status, applicant details, and location (borough). Each entry represents a specific project, identified by a unique ID and name, providing a comprehensive view of land development activities in New York City.

Related Topics:
  - Urban Planning
  - Land Development
  - Zoning Regulations
  - New York City Government
  - Real Estate
  - Municipal Data

Concepts and Synonyms:
  - Land Use Application: Zoning application, development proposal, building permit request
  - ULURP: Uniform Land Use Review Procedure, land use review process
  - Project Status: Application stage, development phase, current status
  - Borough: NYC borough (Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx, Staten Island), geographic location
  - Primary Applicant: Developer, applicant organization, project sponsor

Applications and Use Cases:
  - Track land use trends and development patterns in NYC.
  - Analyze the efficiency of the land use application process.
  - Identify potential development opportunities based on project status and location.
  - Study the impact of zoning regulations on urban development.
  - Understand the types of projects being proposed by different applicant types.

title: DOB NOW: Build Elevator Permit Applications
ufd: This dataset contains information on elevator permit applications filed through the DOB NOW: Build portal. It includes details on new, subsequent, and post-approval amendment filings related to elevator projects (ELV1). Each row represents a job filing and provides information such as the job filing number, filing date, filing type (e.g., New Filing, PAA, Subsequent Filing), and the type of elevator device (e.g., Elevator, Personnel Hoist). The filing status column indicates the current status of the application (e.g., Signed Off, Approved, Withdrawn). Location information, including house number, street name, zip code, borough, block, and lot, is also provided. Researchers, city planners, and developers can use this dataset to analyze trends in elevator installations, monitor the status of permit applications, and gain insights into building development activities across different boroughs. The building code column indicates the year the building was built.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details elevator permit applications submitted via the DOB NOW: Build portal, encompassing new filings, subsequent filings, and post-approval amendments (PAA) for elevator projects (ELV1). Each record represents a job filing, including the filing number, date, type, elevator device type, and current application status. Location details such as address, zip code, borough, block, and lot are also included, along with the building code indicating the year the building was built.

title: DSNY Litter Basket Inventory
ufd: This dataset provides an inventory of litter baskets managed by the New York City Department of Sanitation (DSNY). It includes the location and type of each litter basket, along with details about its ownership (DSNY, private, or BID). Key columns include `baskettype` (the type of basket), `location_description` (a textual description of the basket's location, often an intersection), and `ownertype` (indicating who owns the basket). The dataset also contains coordinate data (`stateplane_labelx`, `stateplane_labely`, `stateplane_snappedx`, `stateplane_snappedy`) for precise placement. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze litter basket distribution, identify areas with potential littering issues, and optimize resource allocation for waste management. The `direction` column specifies the corner of the intersection where the basket is located. Note that the dataset may not reflect real-time changes in basket location or type due to various factors.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset inventories litter baskets managed by the New York City Department of Sanitation (DSNY). It details the location, type, and ownership (DSNY, private, or BID) of each basket. Coordinate data is included for precise placement, enabling analysis of litter basket distribution across the city.

Related Topics:
- Waste Management

- Litter Basket: Trash can, waste receptacle, refuse container

- Basket Type: Receptacle style, container design

Applications and Use Cases:

- Optimize litter basket placement based on population density or pedestrian traffic.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of different litter basket types.
- Support research on littering behavior and waste management strategies.
- Assist city planners in resource allocation for sanitation services.

title: DOB NOW Elevator Safety Compliance
ufd: This dataset contains information on elevator safety compliance in New York City, as tracked by the Department of Buildings through the DOB NOW: Elevator Compliance Filings module. It includes details on elevators, accessibility lifts, and dumbwaiters. Key columns include the device number, device type (e.g., Elevator), device status (typically "Active"), and the date of the status. The dataset also provides location information via borough, block, and lot. Report filing and inspection dates, such as the dates of the latest Category 1 and Category 5 reports, and periodic inspections, are included. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze elevator safety trends, compliance rates across different boroughs, and the timeliness of inspections and report filings. The data could also be used by building owners and managers to track the compliance status of their elevators.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details elevator safety compliance in New York City, as monitored by the Department of Buildings. It encompasses information on elevators, accessibility lifts, and dumbwaiters, including their status, location, and inspection history. The data tracks report filings and inspection dates, providing insights into compliance trends and timelines.

Related Topics:

Applications and Use Cases:

title: Council Members
ufd: This dataset provides information on city council members, including their name, the district they represent, the borough they serve, and their political party affiliation. Each row represents a unique council member. The 'district' column indicates the specific council district, while 'borough' specifies the borough the district falls within. The 'political_party' column shows the council member's political affiliation. This dataset could be used to analyze the political landscape of the city council, understand the representation of different boroughs, or identify council members by district. Researchers, journalists, or anyone interested in local government can use this data to gain insights into the composition and dynamics of the city council.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on city council members, including their district, borough, and political party affiliation. Each record represents a unique council member. The data allows for analysis of the city council's composition and political landscape.

Related Topics:

- Political Representation
- Borough Demographics

Concepts and Synonyms:
- City Council Member: Councilor, Alderman, Representative
- District: Ward, Constituency, Electoral District
- Borough: County, Parish (in some regions), Administrative Division
- Political Party: Party Affiliation, Political Leaning, Party Membership

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the political party distribution across different boroughs.
- Identify council members representing specific districts.
- Study the demographic representation within the city council.
- Track changes in council composition over time (if historical data is available).
- Compare political affiliations across different districts.

title: DHS Data Dashboard
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the demographics of families and individuals within the Department of Homeless Services (DHS) shelter system. It includes data on average daily census figures for families with children (FWC) and single adults (SA), broken down into different categories. Key columns include `report_date`, which indicates the month the data pertains to, and various `avg_daily_census` columns that show the average number of individuals in different shelter types. The dataset also tracks the number of unique individuals served. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze trends in shelter usage, understand the needs of the homeless population, and evaluate the effectiveness of interventions. This information can help inform resource allocation and improve services for those experiencing homelessness. The data spans multiple years, enabling longitudinal analysis.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on the demographics and shelter usage of families and individuals within the Department of Homeless Services (DHS) shelter system. It includes average daily census figures for families with children and single adults, categorized by shelter type. The data also tracks the number of unique individuals served and spans multiple years, enabling trend analysis.

Related Topics:

title: Street Pothole Work Orders - Closed (Dataset)
ufd: This dataset contains information on closed street pothole work orders in New York City, specifically focusing on potholes inspected and repaired by the Department of Transportation. Each record represents a specific pothole repair job. Key columns include geographic coordinates (`the_geom`) detailing the pothole's location, the names of the streets involved (`onfacename`, `onprimname`, `frmprimname`, `toprimname`), and the borough where the pothole was located (`boro`). The `initby` column indicates the source or initial reporter of the pothole. This dataset could be used to analyze pothole repair patterns across the city, identify areas with high pothole density, or evaluate the efficiency of pothole repair services. Researchers, city planners, and residents can use this data to understand and address infrastructure maintenance needs related to street potholes. The dataset also includes the date the pothole was reported (`rptdate`) and the date the repair was completed (`compldate`), allowing for temporal analysis of repair timelines.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details closed pothole work orders in New York City, documenting pothole repairs completed by the Department of Transportation. Each entry represents a single pothole repair job, including location data, street names, borough information, and reporting source. The dataset also provides the dates of report and completion, enabling analysis of repair timelines.

Related Topics:

- Evaluate the efficiency of pothole repair services by analyzing repair timelines.
- Predict future pothole occurrences based on historical data and environmental factors.
- Visualize pothole locations and repair progress on a map.
- Assess the impact of weather conditions on pothole formation.
- Optimize resource allocation for pothole repair crews.

title: DCWP Consumer Complaints
ufd: This dataset contains information on consumer complaints submitted to the NYC Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (DCWP). Each record includes details about the complaint, such as the date it was received (`intake_date`), the channel through which it was submitted (`intake_channel`), and the category of business involved (`business_category`). You can also find the unique business ID (`business_unique_id`) and name (`business_name`) when available. The dataset tracks the resolution of the complaint, including the `result_date` and `result` of the review. Location information, such as `address_type`, `building_nbr`, `street1`, `city`, `state`, `postcode`, and `borough` are provided to give context to where the complaint originated. Researchers and analysts can use this data to identify trends in consumer complaints, evaluate the effectiveness of DCWP interventions, and gain insights into business practices across New York City.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details consumer complaints filed with the NYC Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (DCWP). It includes information on complaint intake details, business information, complaint resolution, and location data. The data allows for analysis of consumer issues, business practices, and the effectiveness of DCWP interventions in New York City.

  - Analyze complaint resolution times and outcomes.
  - Map the geographic distribution of complaints across NYC boroughs.
  - Evaluate the effectiveness of different intake channels for complaint resolution.
  - Track trends in consumer complaints over time.
  - Investigate specific businesses with a high volume of complaints.

title: Sidewalk Dismissal Inspection Tracking
ufd: This dataset tracks sidewalk dismissal inspection requests and their outcomes, focusing on properties where owners have privately repaired sidewalks. It includes details such as the service request number (`sr`), the date the request was made (`request_date`), and the street address of the site (`site_street_address`). Location information is further specified using borough codes (`borocode`) and community board districts. The dataset also contains information on the violation (`violation`), any associated permits (`permit`), and whether the work was performed by a homeowner or a contractor (`homeowner_contractor`). Inspection details, including the assigned date (`assigned_date`), inspection date (`inspection_date`), and pass/fail status (`pass_fail`), are included where available. This data could be used to analyze trends in sidewalk repair requests, assess the effectiveness of private sidewalk repairs, or identify areas with high rates of sidewalk violations. Researchers and city planners could use this information to improve sidewalk maintenance programs and resource allocation.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on sidewalk dismissal inspection requests for properties where owners have privately repaired sidewalks. It includes details on the request, location, violation, permits, and inspection results. The data can be used to analyze trends in sidewalk repair requests and assess the effectiveness of private sidewalk repairs.

- Predict future sidewalk repair needs based on historical data.

title: Small Business Services (SBS) Equal Employment Opportunity (EO 50) Certified Businesses
ufd: This dataset provides a list of businesses certified by the NYC Department of Small Business Services (SBS) for compliance with Equal Employment Opportunity (EO 50) requirements. The data includes the date of EO50 approval, business name, phone number, street address, city, state, and postcode. Location data such as borough, latitude, and longitude are also included, although these fields have a high percentage of missing values. Additional administrative location information is provided through community board and council district. Researchers and analysts can use this dataset to understand which businesses are EO 50 certified, analyze the geographic distribution of these businesses, or potentially identify trends in EO 50 compliance across different sectors or locations. The dataset could also be used by businesses to identify potential partners or contractors who meet EO 50 requirements.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: Youth Behavior Risk Survey (High School)
ufd: This dataset contains results from the Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS), focusing on health-related behaviors of high school students. The data includes prevalence estimates, along with lower and upper 95% confidence intervals, for various indicators. Key columns cover topics such as smoking, binge drinking, alcohol consumption, mental health support, soda consumption, adolescent obesity, and physical activity. The `year` column indicates when the survey was conducted, and the `survey` column specifies whether the data comes from YRBS or YBRS. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to monitor trends in adolescent health behaviors, identify risk factors, and evaluate the effectiveness of interventions aimed at improving youth health. The dataset allows for comparisons across different years and provides insights into the prevalence of various health-related issues among high school students.
sfd:

It includes data on smoking, alcohol consumption, mental health, diet, obesity, and physical activity. The dataset allows for tracking trends in adolescent health behaviors over time and comparing results across different survey years.

- Prevalence Estimates (Rates, Proportions)

- Adolescent Health (Teen Health, Youth Health)
- Smoking (Tobacco Use, Vaping)
- Alcohol Consumption (Drinking, Binge Drinking)
- Mental Health (Well-being, Psychological Health)
- Soda Consumption (Sugar-Sweetened Beverages, Soft Drinks)

Applications and Use Cases:
- Monitoring trends in adolescent health behaviors.
- Identifying risk factors associated with poor health outcomes.
- Evaluating the effectiveness of public health interventions.
- Comparing health behaviors across different years.
- Developing targeted health promotion programs.
- Conducting research on adolescent health and well-being.
- Informing public health policy decisions.
